results.title: Iranian nights
results.creator_credit: Susan Lambert, Stuart Menzies, Tony Wright and December Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Grey voyagers”.
66 year old American emigre Louise Firouz lives and works in the remote north eastern corner of Iran. She breeds rare Turkoman horses, and co-ordinates exotic adventure treks into ancient and remote landscapes which attract international visitors. Two Australian women in their late 60s, Nelly Gelich and her friend Joan Beslich, join Louise and her entourage on a trek which follows a path dating back to Alexander the Great. Along the way, they encounter Kurdish nomads whose hospitality and lifestyle have remained unchanged for centuries.

results.title: Cyber sisters
results.creator_credit: Declan Eames, Stuart Menzies, Tony Wright and December Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Grey voyagers”.
72 year old Catherine Walshe overcomes depression and agoraphobia to visit the friends she has made via the Internet. Travelling from her home in Ireland she meets her ‘cyber sisters’ and joins them on a spectacular journey across the United States by train. Catherine begins to rebuild her life as she shares the sights of Niagara Falls, the mid-western prairies and the vastness of the Rocky Mountains with her friends.

results.title: Flying Dutchmen
results.creator_credit: Steve Westh, Stuart Menzies, Tony Wright and December Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Grey voyagers”.
65 year old Jan van Hulsen teams up Fred van`t Riet to sail a 37 foot yacht from Guatemala to Australia. Hindered by poor weather, delays and clashes of opinion, they don’t travel much further than the Caribbean. Still grieving the recent death of his wife, Jan perseveres through the loneliness and hardship to chart a new direction in his life.

results.title: Father's footsteps
results.creator_credit: Erika Addis, Stuart Menzies, Tony Wright and December Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Grey voyagers”.
80 year old Coffs Harbour identical twins Toni and Adelie Hurley travel to Antarctica on a voyage commemorating Ernest Shackleton’s ill-fated expedition of 1914-16. Their father, Australian director and cinematographer Frank Hurley, was the official photographer aboard the ‘Endurance’ which was crushed by ice as it approached Antarctica, leaving the entire crew stranded on the flows for 6 months. Forced to take to the open sea in 3 small boats when the ice broke, the crew eventually landed on uninhabited Elephant Island and remained there until Shackleton organised their rescue. Toni and Adelie recount their memories of their father as they return to the region where he struggled to survive. During their voyage, they discuss their father’s photographs and diary with Jonathon Shackleton, a relative of the Irish explorer, as they approach Elephant Island. Adelie Hurley also talks about her own career, and her status as Australia’s first female press photographer. Cinematography by Erika Addis. Edited by Tony Stevens. Narrated by Anne Phelan.

results.title: Born to ride
results.creator_credit: Steve Westh, Catherine Marciniak, Stuart Menzies, Tony Wright and December Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Grey voyagers”.
Mechanic Doug Sunderland has been riding motorbikes for 60 years. At 75 years of age, he sets out on a journey to ride through India and Nepal, overcoming ill-health and a collision to celebrate the new Millennium and 2 million kilometres in the saddle. During his voyage, he recounts the 6 years he spent in an orphanage, suggesting it fueled his desire to seek nature and open spaces. Doug also visits Rumtek Monastery in Sikkim. Cinematography by Catherine Marciniak. Edited by Tony Stevens. Narrated by Anne Phelan.

results.title: Mavis goes to Timor
results.creator_credit: Catherine Marciniak, Steve Westh, Stuart Menzies, Tony Wright and December Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Grey voyagers”.
86 year old Mavis Taylor travels from Yarrawonga to East Timor on her first trip overseas. Against the odds, she plans to establish a sewing co-operative for the local women. Frustrated by bureaucracy, Mavis seeks assistance from the local community to help her transform an abandoned hospital into a warehouse and training centre for the co-operative. Her determination and perseverance is rewarded when the first order arrives and a group of local women are trained and organised to meet the delivery deadline. The project provides an opportunity for the women to establish economic security and independence for themselves and their community. During her stay in East Timor, Mavis also visits a church whose congregation was massacred by the Indonesian militia. Cinematography by Catherine Marciniak. Edited by Andrea Lang. Narrated by Anne Phelan.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Catherine Marciniak, Steve Westh, Stuart Menzies, Tony Wright and December Films

results.title: Daria
results.creator_credit: Susie Lewis, Paramount Pictures and MTV
results.brief_description: The unlikely heroine of this offbeat animated MTV series is a cynical and quick witted teenage outsider named Daria Morgendorffer. Her cutting barbs are of course a way of coping with her vacuous teenage sister, her indifferent parents and the cliquey high school she attends which would be complete hell if it wasn’t for her like minded best friend, Jane.

results.title: Nurses
results.creator_credit: Ivo Burum, Helen Gaynor, Alfred Hospital and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: This is real reality TV. A four part series filmed by four nurses at the Alfred Hospital in Melbourne, Nurses demysitifys the soap opera version of hospital practice that usually dominates TV -and it makes for dramatic viewing. A documentary that is also a commitment to egalitarian film-making, Nurses is a real life drama brought into being through the varied experiences and above all narrative ability of its four makers and subjects. From Jane Newham in Emergency, and Cassie Steward in Theatre we get all the immediacy, fast paced excitment and yes, blood and gore of critical medicine and from Kerryn O’Rourke in oncology and Psychiatric Nurse to the homeless, Trish Builic, we see the ongoing patient relationships and responsibilities that are just as much a part of nurseing as the medical administration. Ultimately however the distinctions don’t remain that clear and it is the finely nuanced political and personal concerns combined with the passion and depth of feeling of the women that really makes this series. The espisodic breakdown is gathered under four headings; Episode 1 “Nurses are Tough” introduces us to the women and their hospital setting. Episode 2 “Work Around the Clock” brings us further into the women’s personal lives and how they cope with the 24 hour 7 day a week work schedual. Episode 3 “Coping with Death” explores the coping mechanisms nurses employ in a job that brings them face to face with mortality daily. Episode 4 “Is there life after Death?” questions wether the historical alignement of nurseing and spirituality are still a contemporary motivation or is does it inspire and appeal moreso to a secular humanitarianism. Nurses is not afraid of emphasising that in this profession the personal is the political. There is political undercurrent to the series and it engages sensitivly with institutional issues such the state of the Australian healthcare system, nurseing burn out rates, hospital heriarchies - particularly the status of Nurses compared to Doctors and the old saying “overworked and underpaid”. It also subtly but decidedly examines wider community concerns such as the workability of community care and issues surrounding drug abuse and community attitudes to mental health. Facts and Figures. Courtesy ABC website: 2 years in development, 127 hours of original footage shot between Oct. 1999 and Jan 2000. 1-3 person crews, including nurse, with Helen Gaynor providing directorial support.

results.title: Is there life after death?
results.creator_credit: Ivo Burum, Helen Gaynor, Alfred Hospital and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Nurses”.
Nurses “was filmed by four nurses and their friends at the Alfred Hospital in Melbourne to capture the real life drama of nursing from a very different perspective…their own” Nurses are: Kerryn O’Rourke - Oncology. Trish Builic - Psychiatric (to the homeless). Jane Newham - Emergency. Cassie Steward - Theatre. Ep 4. With Christmas and the Millenium coming up there are conclusions and last comments. There are holidays taken, shopping to be done and religion and beliefs are reflected upon. Jane demystifies the bed pan. One of Kerryn’s patients has rapidly deteriorated. Cassie becomes a patient. And Trish gets frustrated at the outpouring of good will on Christmas day and wonders where it all goes for the rest of the year.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ivo Burum, Helen Gaynor, Alfred Hospital and ABC-TV (Australia)

results.title: Coping with death
results.creator_credit: Ivo Burum, Helen Gaynor, Alfred Hospital and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Nurses”.
Nurses “was filmed by four nurses and their friends at the Alfred Hospital in Melbourne to capture the real life drama of nursing from a very different perspective…their own” Nurses are: Kerryn O’Rourke - Oncology. Trish Builic - Psychiatric (to the homeless). Jane Newham - Emergency. Cassie Steward - Theatre. Ep 3: This episode examines the kind of thoughts and coping mechanisms the nurses have developed in a job that obviously has a high mortality rate. And in particular reflects upon the naivete of the ‘I am going to be a nurse to help people’ idea that all four women have had to deal with. This episode elaborates upon a patient relationship that we have already seen Kerryn commit to. She talks about the way she has necessarily become more detached and that some days, especially with staff shortages the physical side of nursing of observing patients and administering medication means that you just don’t have the ability to feel sad. And that the flip side to this is that ultimately patients appreciate the kindness, understanding and sensitivity given by nurses not if they got their medication on time. Trish talks about the sense of emotions being at either end of the spectrum, that when someone commits suicide or an assault occurs it’s a big jolt in reminding her how crucial the job is. Jane talks about the ‘controlled voice’ she finds herself using when something really serious is happening.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ivo Burum, Helen Gaynor, Alfred Hospital and ABC-TV (Australia)
